Related Publication.Citation: Lees, M., Seal, R. F., Spady, D., Csanyi-Fritz, Y., Robinson, J. L. (2013), Randomized trial of success of pediatric anesthesiologists learning to use two video laryngoscopes. Pediatric Anesthesia, 23: 435-439.

Grant Information.grantNumber:Grant Agency: Saturn Biomedical Systems; KARL STORZ Endoscopy-America, Inc.

citation:Description.dsDescription:Text: The primary purpose of this study was to establish the ability of pediatric anesthesiologists to learn to use two video laryngoscopes - the GlideScope system (GS) and the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface.

ore:describes.socialscience:Characteristics of Data Co: Baseline intubation times, using direct laryngoscopy, were determined for each anesthesiologist on 20 children. Anesthesiologists were then randomized to perform 20 intubations with the GS or KS before crossing over to the other device. The Cormack and Lehane score was compared at baseline and with each of the video laryngoscopes.
ore:describes.Alternative Title: Success of Pediatric Anesthesiologists in Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes
ore:describes.socialscience:Universe: 1) Children being intubated for surgery 2) Anesthesiologists who care for children at Stollery Children's Hospital
ore:describes.Subject: Medicine, Health and Life Sciences
ore:describes.Title: Anesthesiologists Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes in Children
ore:describes.socialscience:Sampling Procedure:
13 anesthesiologists participated in the study; 14 anesthesiologists agreed to participate, but one
relocated before using the VLSs. Data were incomplete for eight other anesthesiologists as there were errors in recording of data or they became reluctant to participate or relocated. All anesthesiologists remained in their assigned groups throughout the study, and none had previous VLS experience. A total of 646 patients were recruited from 2007 through 2011.
ore:describes.socialscience:Frequency: Data was collected at baseline and at times of intubation.
ore:describes.schema:name: Anesthesiologists Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes in Children

dvcore:fileTermsOfAccess.dvcore:availabilityStatus: Data was kept for five years, but has since been destroyed.

ore:describes.schema:includedInDataCatalog: Women and Children's Health Research Institute (WCHRI)
